content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Ryan Otoole: Well, I was born in Portland, Oregon, and I've spent most of my life here. Growing up, my family was pretty average—my dad didn't go to college, just finished high school, and worked a steady job, while my mom earned a bachelor's degree and has always been pretty career-focused. We lived in a modest house on Pine Street, and I remember growing up with a lot of family dinners and holidays with relatives from Ireland. I was raised as a Protestant, but I haven't been religious for a while now. I went to a public high school, and after that, I took a few years off before starting community college. I'm still in school now, working toward a degree in something I'm interested in, though I haven't decided exactly what yet. Life hasn't been too dramatic—no big moves or dramatic events, just the usual ups and downs of growing up, figuring out who I am, and trying to find my path.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Ryan Otoole: Yeah, there was a moment like that—right after high school. I wasn't sure what I wanted to do, and I didn't want to just jump into college right away. So I took a year off and worked at a local bookstore on the edge of town. It was a small place, owned by an older couple who had been there for decades. I learned a lot from them, not just about books, but about patience, about people, and about the quiet kind of life that can be fulfilling in its own way. But after a while, I started to feel like I was just going through the motions. I wasn't growing, and I wasn't really challenged. That's when I realized I needed to push myself, to take that next step. I went back to school, started at community college, and slowly began to figure out what I was interested in. That experience at the bookstore was a crossroads—it showed me what I didn't want, but it also gave me the perspective I needed to make a decision that felt right for me.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Ryan Otoole: I think it was a conscious choice, but not one I made all at once. It was more like a slow realization, like when you're walking through a forest and you suddenly notice the path you're on isn't the one you wanted to take. I didn't have a big moment with a lightbulb going off or anything dramatic. It was more about feeling stuck and then deciding, okay, I need to move forward. I think I was lucky in that I had people around me—my mom, especially—who encouraged me to keep going. She always said, 'If you don't take the risk, you'll always wonder what could have been.' That stuck with me. So I made the choice to go back to school, even though I was scared and unsure. I think that moment at the bookstore was the push I needed to realize I didn't want to be in a place where I wasn't growing. It wasn't just about education, it was about finding purpose, and that choice to take that step has shaped a lot of who I am today.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Ryan Otoole: Yeah, I think someone or something could have definitely helped. I remember talking to a teacher once, Mr. Delaney, who noticed I was kind of drifting after high school. He didn't push me, but he did ask me what I was thinking about doing, and he said something like, 'Sometimes the hardest part is just starting.' That stuck with me. I wish I had reached out more to people like him or maybe even a counselor at the community college. I think having someone to talk to about the fear of failure or the pressure to have everything figured out would have made a difference. But I also think I needed to be in that place where I felt stuck before I could make the change. It wasn't just about getting help—it was about being ready to accept it.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Ryan Otoole: Right now, I don't have a partner or children. My family is pretty small—just my parents and my younger sister, Claire. She's in her early twenties too, and she's actually the one who pushed me to go back to school. She was always the more driven one, and I think she saw me kind of stuck and wanted me to have a better path than she thought I was on. My parents are still pretty involved in my life, even though they're not the most hands-on. My dad works at a local manufacturing plant, and my mom is a nurse at one of the hospitals here in Portland. They both support me, even if they don't always understand what I'm studying or why I'm still in school. I think my sister is the one who really gets it, though. She's studying business, and she always says I need to find something that makes me excited to get up in the morning. I don't know what that is yet, but I'm working on it.

Going through those interview questions made me reflect on how much my life has been shaped by the people around me and the small, often quiet decisions I've made along the way. It's funny how something as simple as working at a bookstore became a turning point, showing me what I didn't want and pushing me to seek something more. I never thought of it as a crossroads at the time, but looking back, it was a moment that defined my path. I also realized how much my family, especially my sister, has influenced me without even realizing it. Their support and belief in me have been important, even when I wasn't sure what I wanted. It's been a journey of figuring things out as I go, and I think that's okay. I'm still learning, still growing, and I'm grateful for the people who've helped me along the way.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Ryan Otoole: My grandparents are still around, though they live in Ireland now. My grandfather on my mom's side was a teacher there, and he always had this way of making you feel like you could do anything if you just tried. My grandmother, on the other hand, was more the storyteller in the family—she'd sit for hours and tell us about growing up in Dublin, about the way the streets looked back in the day, and about her own struggles to get where she wanted to be. I don't see them as often as I'd like, but when I do, it's always like stepping back into a different time. My mom still keeps in touch with them, and she'll often share stories from their letters. I think that's why I always felt connected to Ireland, even though I was born here. It's like part of me is there, even if I've never set foot in the country. I guess that's why I always say I'm a Portlander with an Irish heart.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Ryan Otoole: Yeah, there are a few friends who have been important to me over the years. One of them is Jordan, who I met in high school. We were in the same classes, and we kind of grew up together. He ended up going to a different college, but we still keep in touch. He's always been the more adventurous one, and I think he's the one who made me realize that life doesn't have to be safe or predictable to be worth living. Then there's Sam, who I met when I started working at the bookstore. She was a regular customer, always picking up a few books and staying for hours. We talked about everything—books, music, life, the future. She was the one who really made me think about what I wanted out of life, and she encouraged me to take that step back to school. I don't know if I would have done it without her. I guess what I'm trying to say is, even though my life hasn't been super dramatic, the people I've met along the way have made all the difference. They've been the ones who pushed me, challenged me, and reminded me that I'm capable of more than I sometimes believe.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Ryan Otoole: I live in a pretty quiet neighborhood on the east side of Portland, just a few blocks from the community college I go to. It's a mix of older homes and some newer apartments, and there's this little park right down the street where I like to sit and read or just think. The area has this kind of laid-back vibe, which I guess fits with my personality. There's a lot of young people around—students, artists, people who are just starting out in life. I like that about it. It feels like a place where things are still unfolding, and you can be part of that process. There's a coffee shop nearby that I go to almost every day, and the owner, Ms. Lin, knows me by name. She's one of those people who just makes you feel at home, even if you're just there for a cup of coffee. I think the neighborhood has helped me in a lot of ways, just by being a place where I can be myself without too much pressure. It's not perfect, but it's comfortable, and that's something I really value right now.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Ryan Otoole: I feel pretty safe here, honestly. It's not one of those neighborhoods where you have to lock your doors or worry about walking alone at night, which is nice. There's a sense of community, even if it's not super formal. People know each other, and there's this unspoken understanding that we're all just trying to get by and make the most of our lives. I think that contributes to the safety—not just in a physical sense, but in the way people treat each other. I've never had any real issues, and I think that's because the neighborhood has this kind of quiet respect for one another. It's not perfect, but it feels like a place where I can be myself without fear, and that's something I really appreciate.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Ryan Otoole: Living here has had its ups and downs, like anywhere. The quiet, laid-back vibe is great for someone like me who doesn't need a lot of noise or chaos to feel grounded. I like being close to the college, and the fact that I can walk to most places without a car is a relief. But it's not without its challenges. Sometimes, being in a place where everyone's still figuring things out can be a bit overwhelming. There's this pressure to be successful or to have your life together by a certain age, and I think that's something a lot of people here feel. I've definitely felt that pressure, especially when I was stuck in that bookstore phase, wondering if I was just wasting time. But at the same time, there's something comforting about being surrounded by people who are in the same boat. You don't feel alone in your uncertainty. I think that's one of the things I like most about it—it's a place where you can be in transition without feeling like you're falling behind.

Going through the interview questions about my family and neighborhood made me realize how much my sense of self is tied to the people and places around me. Talking about my family, especially my sister and parents, reminded me of how their support—whether direct or quiet—has been a constant in my life. It's funny how I never really thought about how much my sister pushed me to go back to school until I was asked about it. And when I described my neighborhood, it felt like I was describing a part of myself: quiet, laid-back, and still figuring things out. I think that's why I feel so comfortable here—it mirrors the way I'm trying to live my life, not in a rush, but with purpose. The questions also made me think about how safety and community aren't just about physical security, but about feeling seen and accepted. I didn't realize how much that mattered until I was asked to reflect on it.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Ryan Otoole: A typical week for me is pretty consistent, but there are definitely some variations depending on my classes and how much I'm juggling. I usually wake up around 8 or 9 in the morning, have a quick breakfast—something simple like toast and coffee—and then head to class. I'm taking a mix of general education courses and some intro-level classes in what I think might be my eventual field, though I'm still not entirely sure what that is. I like the flexibility of community college, where I can explore different subjects without feeling like I'm committing to a path too early. After class, I'll usually stop by the coffee shop near my apartment, chat with Ms. Lin for a bit, and then head back home to study or just relax. On days when I don't have class, I'll often spend the morning at the park, reading or just thinking, and then maybe meet up with Jordan or Sam for lunch or a walk. I try to keep a pretty balanced schedule, but there are definitely days when I get caught up in assignments or just need to take a step back and breathe. It's not always perfect, but it's a rhythm that feels right for me right now.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Ryan Otoole: Right now, I work part-time at a local library a few blocks from my apartment. It's not a huge job—just a few afternoons a week, usually on Tuesdays and Thursdays from 2 to 5 p.m.—but it's flexible enough to fit around my classes and study time. The library is a bit quieter than the bookstore I used to work at, which is nice. I help with checking books in and out, organizing shelves, and sometimes assisting people with finding what they need. It's a good way to stay connected to the community and also gives me a chance to read a lot more than I otherwise would. I think it's also helped me stay grounded, especially when I'm feeling overwhelmed with school. The best part is that the library has this old, wooden desk I work at, and it's got this little engraving on the corner that says 'Knowledge is power.' I don't know if I believe that completely, but it's a reminder that I'm doing something that matters, even if it's small.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Ryan Otoole: Outside of work and school, I try to keep a few other routines going. I've been trying to get into a habit of exercising a few times a week—usually on mornings when I don't have class, I'll go for a run around the park or do some yoga at home. It's not always easy to stick with, but I've found that it helps me feel more centered, especially when I'm dealing with a lot of stress or uncertainty. I also like to cook on the weekends, mostly simple meals like pasta or stir-fry. It's something I used to do with my mom when I was younger, and it always reminds me of home. I think those little things—like cooking or running—help me stay grounded and remind me that even though I'm still figuring things out, I'm not completely lost. They give me a sense of control in a life that sometimes feels a bit out of my hands.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Ryan Otoole: One of the bigger changes to my routine has been starting to take online courses in addition to my in-person classes. It's been a bit of an adjustment, but I think it's helping me explore more subjects without feeling like I'm spreading myself too thin. I've been taking a few classes on history and literature, which I never really got into in high school, but now I find myself really enjoying them. It's interesting how something that felt like a chore before can become something I actually look forward to. I also started volunteering at a local community center a few weeks ago, helping out with tutoring and organizing book drives. It's not a huge commitment, just a couple of hours a week, but it's given me a sense of purpose beyond just school and work. I think I'm starting to realize that growth doesn't always come from big, dramatic changes—it can be in the little things, like trying something new or helping someone else out. It's been a good reminder that I'm still learning, and that's okay.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Ryan Otoole: I don't have children yet, but I think about what it would be like if I did. I imagine a typical weekday for them would start early, maybe around 7 or 8 in the morning, with breakfast and getting ready for school. I'd want them to have a good balance between academics and play, so after school, they might have some time to do homework, then maybe participate in an after-school activity like sports or art. I think I'd encourage them to explore their interests, just like my sister did with me. I'd also want them to feel supported, to know that it's okay to make mistakes and that learning is a lifelong journey. I guess I'm still figuring out what kind of parent I'd be, but I know I'd want to create a home that's full of love, curiosity, and a little bit of chaos—because that's what makes life interesting.

Going through the interview questions from 11 to 15 made me reflect on how much my identity is shaped by the people and places around me. Talking about my family reminded me of how their quiet support—especially from my sister and parents—has been a constant in my life, even when I didn't realize it. Describing my neighborhood felt like describing a part of myself: laid-back, still figuring things out, but grounded in a sense of community and safety. It's interesting how I never thought about how much my sister pushed me to go back to school until I was asked about it. And when I described my daily routines, it felt like I was revealing the rhythm of my life—the balance between school, work, and the small, meaningful things like running, cooking, or volunteering. I think these questions helped me see that even though my life hasn't been dramatic, it's been shaped by the people I've met, the places I've lived, and the quiet decisions I've made along the way. It's a reminder that growth doesn't always come from big, dramatic moments—it can be found in the everyday, in the people who support you, and in the little things that help you stay grounded.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Ryan Otoole: In terms of my health, I'd say I'm pretty average—no major issues, but I'm definitely not in the best shape. I used to be more active when I was younger, running around with my sister and playing sports, but as I got older, life got busier, and I started to slip into a more sedentary lifestyle. That's one of the reasons I've been trying to get back into running and yoga lately—it's not just about fitness, though that's part of it. It's also about mental health. I've always been someone who tends to overthink things, and when I'm stressed or feeling stuck, it shows in my body. I get headaches sometimes, and I notice my sleep patterns can be pretty erratic, especially during exam weeks or when I'm juggling a lot of responsibilities. I've started paying more attention to that now, trying to eat better, get enough rest, and take breaks when I need to. It's not perfect, but I think it's a step in the right direction. I've also been talking to a counselor at the community college about managing stress and anxiety, which has been helpful. I think health is one of those things that you don't always prioritize until you realize how much it affects everything else in your life.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Ryan Otoole: What makes it easy to stay healthy, I think, is having a routine that I can stick to—even if it's not perfect. Like, running in the morning or doing yoga when I have time gives me a sense of control, and it helps me feel more grounded. But what makes it hard is the constant juggling act between school, work, and trying to figure out my future. There are days when I'm so caught up in assignments or worrying about what's next that I forget to eat properly or get enough sleep. I also think the pressure to be productive all the time can be counterproductive. I've realized that sometimes, taking a break or just sitting with my thoughts is just as important as staying active. It's a balance I'm still learning, but I'm trying to be kinder to myself when I slip up. After all, health isn't just about being perfect—it's about showing up for yourself, even on the tough days.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Ryan Otoole: In the past two years, I haven't had any major medical diagnoses or serious health issues, but there have been a few things that stood out. I started experiencing more frequent headaches, especially during stressful times like midterms or when I was juggling a lot of responsibilities. At first, I just thought it was stress, and I tried to manage it with better sleep and eating habits, but it didn't go away completely. Eventually, I made an appointment with a doctor, and they ran some tests. Turns out, I have mild hypertension—nothing too serious, but it was a wake-up call. It made me realize how much my lifestyle had been affecting my body without me even noticing. Since then, I've been more consistent with my routines, like eating at regular times, staying hydrated, and making sure I get enough rest. I also started seeing a counselor at the community college, which has helped me manage the stress better. It's been a learning experience, but I'm glad I took the step to check in on my health. It's easy to ignore your body when life feels overwhelming, but I've come to see that taking care of yourself isn't just about being healthy—it's about being present in your life, even when things feel uncertain.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Ryan Otoole: Honestly, my health issues haven't really gotten in the way of my work or daily life, but they've definitely made me rethink how I approach stress and responsibility. The headaches and the hypertension diagnosis were a wake-up call, and while I haven't had to take time off from work or school, they've forced me to slow down and be more intentional about how I manage my time and energy. I used to think that pushing through stress was the only way to get things done, but now I see that it's not sustainable. It's affected how I approach my studies—instead of trying to cram everything in, I'm learning to pace myself, take breaks, and listen to my body when it's telling me to rest. I think that's been a good thing in the long run, even if it's been a bit of an adjustment. It's not like I'm perfect at it, but I'm trying to be more mindful of how my health impacts everything else in my life.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Ryan Otoole: Over the past year, I've been feeling a mix of things—mostly a sense of slow but steady progress, even if it's not always obvious. I think I've been more aware of how my mental and physical health are connected, and that's been a big shift for me. I used to push through stress without really thinking about how it was affecting me, but now I try to check in with myself more often. I've been trying to be kinder to myself, especially when I'm struggling with school or feeling unsure about my future. There have been moments when I've felt overwhelmed, especially when I'm juggling a lot of responsibilities, but I've also had times when I felt a real sense of purpose—like when I started volunteering at the community center or when I finished a tough assignment and realized I'd made it through. I think I'm still figuring out what it means to be in control of my own life, but I'm starting to see that it's not about having everything figured out—it's about showing up, even when it's hard, and trusting that things will work out in their own time.

Going through the interview questions from 16 to 20 made me reflect on how much my health and daily routines are intertwined with the rest of my life. Talking about my recent changes, like taking online courses and volunteering, reminded me that growth doesn't always come from big, dramatic moments—it can be found in the small, consistent choices I make every day. It also made me realize how much my mental and physical health affect everything else, from my ability to focus in school to how I feel about myself overall. I used to think that being busy meant I was productive, but now I see that taking care of myself—whether it's through exercise, better sleep, or even just taking a break when I need to—is just as important. These questions also made me think about how I've been learning to be kinder to myself, especially when I'm struggling with uncertainty or stress. I used to feel like I had to have everything figured out, but now I'm starting to see that it's okay to be in the process of figuring things out. It's not about perfection—it's about showing up for myself, even on the tough days.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Ryan Otoole: I think I've struggled with anxiety more than anything else, especially around the pressure of making decisions about my future. There were times when I felt like I was stuck in this loop of uncertainty—wondering if I was making the right choices, if I was going to end up in a job I didn't like, or if I'd ever find something that truly excited me. It wasn't full-blown depression, but there were definitely days when I felt weighed down by the weight of it all. I remember one particular moment during my first semester at community college when I was overwhelmed with assignments and worried about whether I was on the right path. I didn't want to disappoint my family or myself, and that pressure made it hard to breathe sometimes. But I've been working on it—talking to a counselor, practicing mindfulness, and learning to be more patient with myself. I still have days when the anxiety creeps in, but I'm starting to see that it's not something I have to be afraid of. It's just part of being human, and I'm learning how to manage it without letting it define me.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Ryan Otoole: For my family, it's been a mix of support and concern, especially with me still figuring things out. My parents have always been there for me, but I think they've been worried about whether I'm making the right choices or if I'm going to end up stuck in the same place I was after high school. They don't say it out loud, but I can tell they're proud of me for going back to school, especially since I didn't have a clear plan at first. My mom, in particular, has been really encouraging—she always reminds me that it's okay to take your time and that success doesn't have to look the same for everyone. My dad, on the other hand, is more reserved, but he's shown his support in quieter ways, like making sure I have a meal ready when I get home from class or checking in on me when I'm stressed. My sister, Claire, has been the most vocal about it. She's always pushing me to be better, to take risks, and to not settle for anything less than what I want. She's the one who really made me realize that I didn't have to be afraid of uncertainty. Even though it's been tough for them to watch me go through this process, I think they've been patient because they know I'm trying my best. It's not always easy, but I'm grateful for their love and support—it's been a big part of why I've been able to keep going.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Ryan Otoole: I think religion or spirituality hasn't been a big part of my life for a while now, though it's something I've thought about from time to time. I was raised as a Protestant, and I remember going to church with my family when I was younger, especially around holidays or during important family events. My mom was more involved in that than my dad, who was pretty laid-back about it. But as I got older, I started to feel like the structure and rituals didn't really resonate with me anymore. I never really questioned it at the time—I just kind of drifted away. Now, I don't think of myself as religious, but I do believe in something bigger than myself, even if I can't put it into words. I think it's more about the quiet moments, the way the world feels when you're sitting in a park or watching the sunrise, and how those moments remind you that you're part of something larger. I don't know if that's spirituality or just being reflective, but it's something that helps me feel grounded, especially when I'm feeling lost or unsure about my path.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Ryan Otoole: I don't use social media too much, honestly. I know a lot of people my age are always on their phones, scrolling through Instagram or Facebook, but I've never really felt the need for it. I guess I'm more of a behind-the-scenes kind of person—someone who prefers face-to-face conversations or just sitting in a park with a book rather than trying to curate a perfect online image. I do have a Facebook account, mostly to keep in touch with family back in Ireland and to see what my old high school friends are up to, but I don't post much. Instagram feels even more performative, like everyone's trying to show off their best moments, and I just don't want to be part of that. I think it's more about how I see the world—quiet, real, and not always perfect. I don't mind being offline, and I think it's helped me stay more present in my own life rather than getting lost in someone else's highlight reel.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Ryan Otoole: Honestly, I don't think I've ever really relied on social media for support during tough times. I know a lot of people use it to vent or find encouragement, but I've always found that kind of thing overwhelming. I prefer talking to someone in person, like my sister or a friend I trust, rather than posting something online and hoping someone responds. I guess I feel like social media can sometimes make things worse—like, seeing everyone else's highlight reels when I'm feeling down just makes me feel more alone. That said, I do appreciate the way Facebook keeps me connected to my family in Ireland, especially during holidays or when I'm feeling homesick. It's not perfect, but it's enough for me.

Going through the interview questions from 21 to 25 made me reflect on how much my health and mental well-being have shaped the way I approach life. Talking about my recent health changes, like being diagnosed with mild hypertension, reminded me that my body is constantly telling me things if I'm willing to listen. It also made me realize how much stress and uncertainty can take a toll on both my mind and body, and how important it is to take care of myself—even when it feels hard. Discussing my struggles with anxiety brought up a lot of feelings I hadn't fully acknowledged before, like the pressure of making decisions about my future and the fear of not being good enough. But it also gave me a sense of relief, knowing that I'm not alone in feeling this way and that it's okay to seek help. It's funny how something as simple as checking in on my health or talking to a counselor can make such a big difference in how I see myself and my life. These questions made me realize that growth isn't just about big moments or dramatic changes—it's also about learning to be kinder to myself, even when things feel overwhelming.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Ryan Otoole: In the past few months, I've noticed my stress levels have been a bit lower, which I think is because I've been more intentional about how I manage my time and take care of myself. I used to worry a lot about not having everything figured out, but I've started to accept that it's okay to be in the process. I've been using some new coping strategies, like journaling when I feel overwhelmed or going for a run when my mind is racing. I've also been trying to be more present in the moment, whether it's during class, at work, or just sitting in the park. It's not always easy, but I've found that when I focus on the small things—like a good cup of coffee, a conversation with a friend, or even just the sound of birds chirping—it helps me feel more grounded. I think I'm still learning, but I'm starting to see that stress isn't something I have to fight all the time—it's something I can manage, and sometimes, just letting it pass through me without resisting is enough.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Ryan Otoole: Last month, my biggest expenses were rent, groceries, and tuition. I live in a small apartment on the east side of Portland, and the rent is about $800 a month. It's not too bad for the area, but it takes up a good chunk of my budget. Groceries are another thing—since I try to cook most of my meals at home, I end up spending around $200 to $250 a month on food. Tuition at the community college is about $100 per credit, and I'm taking around 12 credits this semester, so that's roughly $1,200 for the term. I also have some other smaller expenses, like transportation, utilities, and the occasional coffee or meal out. I work part-time at the library, which helps cover some of these costs, but I still have to be pretty careful with my money. I've been trying to track my spending more closely, and I've also started setting aside a little bit each month for emergencies. It's not much, but it's something. I think the hardest part is balancing everything without feeling like I'm constantly stretched thin. It's a learning process, but I'm trying to be more mindful of where my money goes and how I can make the most of it without sacrificing my well-being.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Ryan Otoole: My household spending last month was pretty close to what I usually spend, though there were a few minor fluctuations. On average, I spend around $1,200 to $1,300 a month, depending on how much I need to set aside for unexpected things. Rent is the biggest chunk, as I mentioned, and then groceries, tuition, and transportation. I usually try to keep my expenses as predictable as possible, but there are always little things that come up—like a new pair of shoes, a book I really want, or a weekend meal out with friends. I've been trying to be more mindful of where my money goes, and I've started using a simple budgeting app to track my spending. It's helped me see where I can cut back or adjust, like buying in bulk for groceries or using public transportation more instead of driving. I know it's not perfect, but it's given me a better sense of control over my finances, which is something I really needed.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Ryan Otoole: We rent our home. It's a small one-bedroom apartment on the east side of Portland, just a few blocks from the community college. Renting has been the practical choice for me right now, especially with the way my schedule is—going back and forth between classes, work, and trying to keep some kind of balance in my life. I don't see myself buying a house anytime soon, not with how uncertain things still feel. It's funny, though, because I used to think that owning a home was this big milestone, something that meant you'd really made it. Now I realize that stability isn't just about where you live—it's about having a sense of direction, even if you're not sure where that direction is leading you. Renting gives me the flexibility to move if I need to, or to adjust my life as I figure things out. I don't know if that makes me sound indecisive, but I think it's just part of being in the process of growing up.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Ryan Otoole: Over the past year, my bills have had their ups and downs, mostly tied to the seasons and my schedule. In the winter, heating costs went up a bit, which I didn't expect since I thought the apartment was pretty well insulated. I had to start using the space heater more, and that added a few extra dollars to my electricity bill. Then there were the holidays—December was a bit more expensive because I bought a few gifts for my family back in Ireland, and I also treated myself to a new pair of running shoes since I've been trying to get back into shape. On the flip side, summer was a bit easier on the budget because I didn't need to use the heater as much, and I was able to save a little more by cooking outside or eating at the park. Tuition costs stayed the same, but I did have to pay for a few extra books this semester, which I hadn't planned for. I've also been trying to be more mindful of my spending, like buying groceries in bulk or using public transportation instead of driving. It's not perfect, but I've learned that my bills aren't as unpredictable as I used to think—they just require a little more attention and planning, especially when I'm trying to balance school, work, and everything else in my life.

Going through the interview questions from 26 to 30 made me reflect on how my family's support and my own mental health have shaped my journey. Talking about my family reminded me of how much their love and patience have helped me through the uncertainty of my path. They've never pushed me too hard, but they've always been there, offering quiet encouragement and understanding. It's comforting to know that even when I feel lost, I'm not alone. Discussing my mental health and anxiety also made me realize how much I've grown in learning to manage stress and take care of myself. I used to think that being productive meant pushing through everything without pause, but now I see that rest and reflection are just as important. I've also come to appreciate that I don't need social media to feel connected or supported—real, meaningful relationships are what truly matter. These questions helped me see that my well-being is not just about big decisions or dramatic changes, but about the small, consistent choices I make every day to stay grounded, healthy, and connected to the people who care about me.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Ryan Otoole: I try to save in small, consistent ways rather than having a formal savings account. It's more of a habit than a strict plan—like setting aside a little bit of my paycheck each week, maybe $20 or $30, into a separate jar or envelope. I don't have a lot, but it's something. I think it started when I realized how easy it is to spend money on things I don't really need, like coffee or snacks when I'm stressed. So I made a rule for myself: if I want to buy something, I have to take it out of that savings jar first. It's not much, but it helps me feel more in control of my money. I also try to save up for bigger things, like textbooks or a new pair of shoes, by tracking my expenses and seeing where I can cut back. I know it's not perfect, and I definitely don't have a huge emergency fund, but I'm learning that saving doesn't have to be about having a lot—it's about being intentional with what you have, even if it's just a little bit at a time.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Ryan Otoole: In the last year, I've been saving more for a rainy day than for big things like a home, mostly because I know how unpredictable life can be right now. I've been trying to build up that little emergency fund, even if it's just a few dollars at a time. It started after I got diagnosed with mild hypertension—it made me realize how important it is to be prepared for unexpected things, whether it's a medical bill, a sudden expense, or just a month where everything feels a little tighter than usual. I don't have a lot, but I try to set aside whatever I can, even if it's just $10 or $20 a week. It's not about having a huge amount; it's about knowing that I have something to fall back on if things get tough. I think that sense of security, even if it's small, helps me feel more in control of my life, especially when everything else feels so uncertain.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Ryan Otoole: My current occupation is working part-time at the local library, which I mentioned earlier, but before that, I was working at a bookstore for a year after high school. The work at the bookstore was pretty straightforward—helping customers find books, restocking shelves, and managing the checkout counter. It was a quiet job, and I learned a lot about patience and paying attention to detail. But it also made me realize that I didn't want to be in a job where I felt like I wasn't growing or learning anything new. That's why I eventually decided to go back to school. Now, working at the library is a bit different—it's still about helping people, but it also gives me a chance to be around books again, which I always loved. I think the most important part of my job, whether it's at the library or the bookstore, is being reliable and making sure people feel welcome. I don't have any grand ambitions about my career right now, but I do hope that whatever I end up doing, it's something that feels meaningful and allows me to keep learning.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Ryan Otoole: I usually work around 15 hours a week at the library, which is pretty manageable with my class schedule. It's not a huge commitment, but it gives me a sense of structure and also helps me stay connected to the community. I like that I can keep my hours flexible, especially since I'm still figuring out what I want to study and how much time I need to dedicate to that. Sometimes, if I have a heavier week with assignments or exams, I'll reduce my hours a bit, and other times, when I feel like I need a break from school, I'll work a little more just to stay grounded. It's a balance, but I think it works for me right now.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Ryan Otoole: Actually, I only had one job at a time, and that was the bookstore after high school. I didn't really take on multiple jobs because I wanted to focus on figuring out what I wanted to do with my life. I think I was afraid of spreading myself too thin, especially when I was still trying to decide if I wanted to go to college or not. Once I went back to school, working part-time at the library was the only job I needed to keep things balanced. I didn't want to overcommit, especially with how uncertain everything still felt. It's funny, though—I used to think having more than one job would make me more responsible or independent, but I think it's better to have one job that fits well with your life and goals. I'm still learning, but I think that's something I've come to understand over time.

Going through the interview questions from 31 to 35 made me reflect on how much my mental health, financial stability, and family support are intertwined in my daily life. Talking about my stress levels and coping strategies reminded me that growth isn't just about big moments—it's also about learning to manage the little things, like anxiety or uncertainty, in a way that feels sustainable. It also made me realize how much my family's quiet support has been a constant in my life, even when I didn't always recognize it. Discussing my finances and budgeting habits brought up how much I've been learning to be more intentional with my money, not just for practical reasons, but also as a way to feel more in control of my life. I used to think that being productive meant pushing through everything without pause, but now I see that rest, reflection, and even small savings can be just as important. These questions helped me see that my well-being isn't just about big decisions or dramatic changes—it's about the small, consistent choices I make every day to stay grounded, healthy, and connected to the people who care about me.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Ryan Otoole: In terms of what my household made last month, it was pretty modest—around $1,500 to $1,600 total, mostly from my part-time job at the library and any small side gigs I pick up now and then, like helping out with local events or tutoring. I don't make a lot, but it's enough to cover the basics. I've been trying to be more intentional about how I spend and save, even if it's just a few dollars at a time. It's not about being rich or having everything figured out—it's about making the most of what I have and knowing that I'm working toward something bigger. I think that's why I'm still in school, even if I'm not sure what I want to do yet. It's not just about the money, it's about having options and feeling like I'm still moving forward, even if it's at a slower pace than some people might expect.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Ryan Otoole: I've been working at the library for about a year now, and it's been a good fit for me. The hours are flexible, which is something I really appreciate because it allows me to balance work with school and my other responsibilities. As for benefits, the library offers a basic health insurance plan that I can enroll in, though I haven't taken it up yet because I'm still figuring out my long-term plans. They also give us a few days of paid time off each year, which is nice to have, even if I don't use it much. I think the biggest benefit of the job, though, is the sense of community it gives me. I've gotten to know a lot of the regulars—students, teachers, even some local authors—and it's made me feel more connected to the place I live. It's not a high-paying job, and it doesn't come with a lot of perks, but it's steady, and it gives me a chance to do something that feels meaningful, even in small ways.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Ryan Otoole: My relationships at work are pretty good overall. I get along well with my coworkers—we're all pretty laid-back and understand the pace of things. We don't have a lot of formal interactions, but there's a sense of mutual respect. My manager, Ms. Carter, is someone I really admire. She's been in the library for years and has this calm, steady presence that makes you feel like you can ask her anything. She's never been pushy or overly demanding, which I think is part of why I've stayed here. I've learned a lot from her, not just about the job, but about how to be patient and how to treat people with kindness. I think the best part of working there is that it feels like a second home in a way—no one is judging you, and everyone just wants to help each other out. It's not the kind of job that changes your life in a big way, but it's the kind of place where you can feel like you belong, and that means a lot to me.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Ryan Otoole: My work schedule is pretty predictable, but it's also flexible enough to fit around my classes and personal life. I usually work the same hours every week—Tuesdays and Thursdays from 2 to 5 p.m.—but if I need to adjust for a test or a project deadline, I can talk to my manager and swap shifts with someone else. That flexibility is something I really appreciate, especially since I'm still figuring out what I want to do with my life. It doesn't feel like I'm being forced into a rigid structure, which is nice. I think that's one of the reasons I've stayed at the library for so long—it gives me the stability I need without being too restrictive. It's not perfect, but it works for me right now.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Ryan Otoole: Overall, I feel like my financial situation is manageable, but it's definitely not easy. I know I'm not struggling in the way that some people do, but I also know that I'm not in a position where I can afford a lot of luxuries or take big risks. It's a balancing act every month—making sure I can cover rent, groceries, and tuition while also trying to save a little for the future. I don't think I'll ever be rich, but I don't mind that. What matters more to me is having enough to get by and feeling like I'm making progress, even if it's slow. I've learned to be grateful for what I have, and I think that's something that's helped me stay grounded. I know I'm not where I want to be financially, but I'm still working toward it, and that's what keeps me going.

Going through the interview questions from 36 to 40 made me reflect on how much my financial situation and work life are intertwined with my overall sense of stability and growth. Talking about how my bills fluctuate throughout the year reminded me that life is full of small, predictable changes—like seasonal costs or holiday expenses—that require a bit of planning and awareness. It also made me think about how my part-time job at the library gives me the flexibility I need to manage my schedule without feeling overwhelmed. I used to worry that I wasn't working hard enough or earning enough, but now I see that it's not about the amount—it's about the balance between work, school, and taking care of myself. Discussing my savings habits and emergency fund also made me realize how important it is to be intentional with money, even in small ways. I used to think saving was something for people who had a lot, but now I see that it's about building a sense of security, no matter how small. These questions helped me see that my financial situation isn't just about numbers on a budget—it's about feeling in control of my life, even when things feel uncertain.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Ryan Otoole: Yes, both my mom and dad worked for pay while I was growing up. My dad worked at a manufacturing plant for over ten years, and even though he didn't go to college, he was pretty steady in his job. He always said it wasn't about making a lot of money—it was about having a job that gave you a sense of purpose and allowed you to provide for your family. My mom, on the other hand, worked as a nurse, and she was the one who really pushed for education, even though she had to balance that with raising us. She went back to school part-time after I was born, and she finished her bachelor's degree when I was around ten. I remember her staying up late studying, and I think that's what really inspired me to value education, even if I didn't always know what I wanted to do with it. Looking back, I think both of them had different approaches to work, but they both showed me that having a job isn't just about money—it's about responsibility, growth, and doing what you can to make life better for the people you care about.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Ryan Otoole: My dad worked at a manufacturing plant, assembling parts for industrial equipment. It was a pretty physical job—he stood on his feet for most of the day, and there was a lot of repetition involved. But he always said it was satisfying in its own way because you could see the end result of your work, even if it was just a small part of a bigger machine. His most important duties were making sure everything was assembled correctly and safely, following the guidelines strictly because even a small mistake could cause problems down the line. He never talked about it much, but I think he took pride in knowing that his work contributed to something bigger, even if he didn't get to see it. My mom, on the other hand, was a nurse at one of the hospitals here in Portland. Her work was more demanding in terms of emotional labor—she was always on her feet, dealing with patients, their families, and the pressures of the healthcare system. Her most important activities were making sure her patients were comfortable, monitoring their conditions, and providing care that went beyond just the medical aspect. I remember her coming home exhausted but also fulfilled, and I think that's what made her work meaningful to her. Both of them had different kinds of jobs, but they both showed me that work isn't just about making money—it's about responsibility, dedication, and doing your best for the people you care about.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Ryan Otoole: My dad worked for a local manufacturing company called Portland Industrial Solutions. It was one of those places where you'd walk in and immediately feel the hum of machines and the smell of metal in the air. They made parts for everything from construction equipment to agricultural machinery. He was part of the assembly line, and while it wasn't the most glamorous job, he always said it had its own kind of rhythm. He'd start his day early, sometimes before sunrise, and spend most of it standing at his station, putting together components with precision. He never talked about the long hours or the physical toll it took on him, but I could tell it was hard work. My mom, on the other hand, worked for a hospital called St. Mary's Medical Center. It was a big, busy place, and she was part of the emergency department. She was always on her feet, moving from one patient to another, and I think that's why she always looked so tired when she came home. She didn't just treat patients—she listened to them, comforted them, and made sure they felt seen. I remember her telling me once that nursing wasn't just about medicine, it was about people, and that stuck with me. Both of them worked in very different places, but they both had a sense of purpose in their jobs, and I think that's something I've carried with me in my own life.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Ryan Otoole: I hope that in a few years, I'm still in a place where I feel grounded and connected to the people and things that matter most to me. I don't know exactly what my career will look like, but I hope it's something that allows me to keep learning and growing, even if it's not something grand or dramatic. I'd like to be in a stable place financially, not necessarily rich, but enough to cover my basics and maybe even have a little extra to save or spend on things that bring me joy. I hope I'm still living in Portland, or maybe somewhere similar—somewhere quiet, where I can walk to work, sit in a park, and feel like I belong. I also hope I'm more confident in myself, less afraid of uncertainty, and more willing to take risks when they feel right. Most of all, I hope I'm still surrounded by people who care about me—my family, my friends, and maybe even someone I love. I think that's what I'm really hoping for: a life that feels full, even if it's not perfect, and a sense that I'm moving forward, even if it's one step at a time.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Ryan Otoole: What I value the most in my life is connection—whether it's with my family, my friends, or even the people I pass by in the park or at the library. I think I've come to realize that life isn't about achieving some grand goal or having everything figured out. It's about the little moments, the conversations, the shared laughter, and the quiet support that people give you when you don't even realize you need it. I value being able to wake up and feel like I belong somewhere, even if it's just in my own little corner of the world. I also value growth—not the kind that happens in a flash, but the slow, steady kind that comes from learning, making mistakes, and trying again. And I value the freedom to choose my own path, even if it's not always clear where that path leads. I think that's why I'm still in school, still exploring, still figuring things out—it's not about having all the answers, but about being open to the possibilities.

Going through the interview questions from 41 to 45 made me reflect on how my work life and financial situation are deeply connected to my sense of stability and purpose. Talking about my income and how it covers my basic needs reminded me that I'm not in a place of abundance, but I'm not struggling either. It's a balance I'm learning to accept. Discussing my job at the library brought up how much I value the flexibility and community it offers, even if it's not a high-paying or prestigious position. It's not about the title or the salary—it's about feeling like I'm contributing and being part of something bigger. My relationships at work, especially with my manager and coworkers, have been a source of support and understanding, which is something I didn't realize I needed until I was asked about it. It's funny how the small things—like a steady schedule, a few days of paid time off, or just having a place where I feel like I belong—can make such a big difference in how I see my life and my future.

Going through this complete interview and life story has been a journey of reflection, not just for the interviewer, but for me as well. It's amazing how much I've learned about myself when I've had to articulate my life, my choices, and my struggles. I never realized how much my family, especially my sister and parents, have shaped me until I was asked to talk about them. I also didn't think about how much my neighborhood and the people in it have influenced my sense of self until I described it in detail. It's funny how the quiet moments—the time I spent at the bookstore, the small routines I've built around school, work, and self-care—have all been part of a larger story that I didn't fully recognize until now. This process has reminded me that my life hasn't been about dramatic changes or big decisions, but about the small, consistent choices I've made and the people who have supported me along the way. I think that's what makes my story real—not because it's perfect, but because it's honest, and it shows that growth doesn't always come from grand moments, but from the everyday, the people, and the quiet decisions that shape who we are.
